docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the lesser-known provisions of the 1982 tax law dramatically changes the way that medical insurance will be offered to workers between the ages of 65 and 70. The change, which took effect at the beginning of this year, makes benefits from an employer's health insurance plan primary to Medicare, the Federal Government's insurance program for people over 65 years old. Previously, the benefits payable under an employer group health plan was secondary to Medicare benefits. ''The employee may now end up with more coverage,'' said Janet E. Shepherd, a partner of Hewitt Associates, a consulting and actuarial firm based in Lincolnshire, Ill., who has studied the new arrangement. ''In the past, you would have to wait to see what Medicare paid first.''

docs.lead_paragraph: In a decision believed to be the first of its kind in the United States, patients confined involuntarily in state mental hospitals have won the right to refuse drugs that are routinely and often forcibly used to treat them for psychosis. Federal District Judge William H. Orrick tentatively approved a consent decree May 13 that would end a class-action suit filed in 1978 on behalf of involuntary patients at Napa State Hospital, California's largest psychiatric facility. It will become effective July 14 after a required waiting period to allow for public notification. While the decree initially affects only Napa Hospital, both sides in the suit expect it to be extended to other state facilities after a year of monitoring by the court. Inquiries about it have been received from other states.

docs.lead_paragraph: The care of tuberculosis depends more on what the patient has in his head than what he has in his chest. - Sir William Osler (1849-1919), the father of modern medicine. NEARLY a century after some leading physicians first recognized the powerful role of the mind in health and healing, scientists have begun to decipher exactly how stress and other emotional states can influence the onset and course of disease. Aided by new biochemical techniques and a vastly expanded understanding of immunology and neurochemistry, their studies show that emotions, acting through the brain, can affect nervous system function, hormone levels and immunological responses, thereby changing a person's susceptibility to a host of organic ills. Depending on the circumstances, animal and human studies have revealed that emotional reactions can suppress or stimulate diseasefighting whiteblood cells and trigger the release of adrenal gland hormones and neurotransmitters, including endorphins, that in turn affect dozens of body processes.
